Portrait of American abolitionist John Brown taken by Augustus Washington in c. 1847. Brown was a leading figure in the abolitionist movement in the years prior to the American Civil War, first reaching national prominence in the 1850s for his radical abolitionism and fighting in Bleeding Kansas. In 1859, Brown was captured, tried, and executed by the Commonwealth of Virginia for his raid on Harpers Ferry. The raid was done in an effort to initiate a slave revolt in southern states by taking control of a federal armory and arsenal. Credit: @julius.backman⁠ #history #johnbrown #usa
Tsar Nicholas II of Russia photographed writing at his desk in the Winter Palace. Photograph taken in c. late 1890s. Credit: @royaltyincolour⁠ #history #nicholasii

The first-class cabin on the world's first purpose-built cruise ship, the 'Prinzessin Victoria Luise', photographed in 1901. The ship was owned and operated by the Hamburg America Line, and its maiden voyage was in 1901. It operated for 5 years until it was damaged hitting a reef when entering a harbor in Kingston, Jamaica. Credit: @color_byangelina⁠ #history #cruise #ship
"Chief" the firehouse dog waiting for the next outing on FDNY Engine 20 in Manhattan, New York City, in 1943. Credit: @color_byangelina⁠ #history #firefighters #dog
A young girl reads a comic book at a supermarket in Anchorage, Alaska, in 1958. Photograph taken by Dmitri Kessel. Credit: @sebcolorisation⁠ #history #supermarket #alaska

Mugshot of American gangster Al Capone taken in May 1930 in Miami, Florida. Florida Governor Doyle E. Carlton declared that Al Capone was not welcome in Florida and officially ordered all sheriffs in the state to arrest and escort Capone to the state line if he entered. Credit: @socolorization⁠ #history #alcapone #miami
Klostergaten, a street in Bergen, Norway, photographed in c. 1910. Credit: @voje.color⁠ #history #bergen #norway

A nurse photographed with German and Astro-Hungarian Prisoners of War at Hald prison camp in Denmark on the 17 August 1917. Credit: @julius.backman⁠ #history #ww1 #denmark

The Dyckman House in New York, United States photographed in the 1890s by James Reuel Smith. The Dyckman House is the oldest remaining farmhouse in Manhattan, and the only one in Dutch Colonial style. It was constructed in c. 1785 by William Dyckman. It is now located in a small park at the corner of Broadway and 204th Street in Inwood, Manhattan, and operates as a museum. Credit: @retrograde_colour #history #nyc #newyork

Tsar Alexander III of Russia embracing his niece Princess Maria of Greece and Denmark (later Grand Duchess Maria Georgievna of Russia). Photograph taken in the early 1890s. Credit: @royaltyincolour⁠ #history #monarchy
Sidewalk scene in Selma, Alabama photographed by by Walker Evans in December 1935. Credit: @sebcolorisation⁠ #history #selma #alabama

A man taking part in a one-man demonstration protesting against unemployment. Photograph taken in the United Kingdom in the 1930s. His sign reads "I know 3 trades, I speak 3 languages, fought for 3 years, have 3 children, and no work for 3 months, but I only want one job." Credit: @color_byangelina⁠ #history

Indian soldiers of the 58th Vaughan's Rifles (Frontier Force) in a trench in Fauquissart, France wearing gas masks in anticipation of a gas attack. Photograph taken by H. D. Girdwood on the 9 August 1915. The Hypo helmet/British Smoke Hood was an early British World War I gas mask introduced in June 1915 and manufactured until September 1915. Credit: @melodie_colors_the_past⁠ #history #wwi #soldiers

Portrait of Tsar Nicholas II of Russia taken in c. 1913. Nicholas II was the last emperor of the Russian Empire, reigning from 1894 until 1917. Credit: @melodie_colors_the_past⁠ #history #nicholasii

Left to Right: Paul McCartney, age 16; Ivan Vaughan, age 16; and George Harrison, age 15. Photograph taken in c. 1958 in Liverpool. Ivan Vaughan is responsible for, in 1957, introducing two of his childhood friends, Paul McCartney and John Lennon, to each other. Paul McCartney, John Lennon, George Harrison, and Ringo Starr as The Beatles would go on to become the best-selling music act of all time. Credit: @spektonzcolorizations⁠ #history #beatles #mccartney #harrison

Finnish sniper Second Lieutenant Simo Häyhä 'The White Death' photographed in the c. 1940s. ⁠ ⁠ Simo Häyhä is generally regarded as the deadliest sniper in history, having killed an estimated 500 enemy soldiers during the Winter War (part of World War II) between November 1939 and March 1940. A week before the end of the war, Häyhä was hit by an explosive bullet that shattered his lower left jaw. He was at first believed to be dead but regained consciousness a week later. Recovery took considerable time and required extensive treatment and multiple surgeries, leaving visible scars that remained for the rest of his life. Häyhä died on the 1 April 2002 at the age of 96. Credit: @julius.backman⁠ #history #winterwar #finland

Okkotsu Wataru, 17-year-old barber with the Japanese embassy in Paris, France, photographed by Jacques-Philippe Potteau in 1864. ⁠ ⁠ The Second Japanese Embassy to Europe, also called the Ikeda Mission, was sent on 6 February 1864 by the Tokugawa shogunate. The objective of the mission was to obtain French agreement to the closure of the harbor of Yokohama to foreign trade. The task proved impossible, as Yokohama was the center of foreign presence in Japan since the opening of the country by Commodore Matthew Perry in 1854. Credit: @julius.backman⁠ #history #japan #paris

Mug shot of Alphonse Bertillon, the inventor of the mug shot, taken on the 7 August 1912. Photographing of criminals began in the 1840s only a few years after the invention of photography, but it was not until 1888 that Bertillon standardized the process. ⁠ ⁠ He also introduced anthropometry to law enforcement, creating an identification system based on physical measurements such as height, head size, and ear length. It was the first scientific system used by police to identify criminals, replacing earlier methods that relied solely on names or photographs. This method was eventually replaced by fingerprinting. Credit: @socolorization⁠ #history #mugshot #photo

Polish-American photographer Theodor Horydczak laying on the grass with his large format camera in the Washington, D.C area in the c. 1920s. Horydczak is best known for photographs of the places, buildings, and events of Washington, DC such as the 1932 Bonus Army encampment and the 1933 World Series. Credit: @julius.backman⁠ #history #photography #photographer

Danish veterans of the Second Schleswig War photographed in 1864. The Second Schleswig War was a conflict with Denmark fighting the Kingdom of Prussia and the Austrian Empire for control of the duchies of Schleswig, Holstein, and Lauenburg, due to the succession disputes concerning them when the Danish king died without an heir acceptable to the German Confederation. The war ended on 30 October 1864, with the Treaty of Vienna and Denmark's cession of the Duchies of Schleswig, Holstein, and Saxe-Lauenburg to Prussia and Austria. Credit: @julius.colorization⁠ #history #soldiers #veteran

Yatsou Kousirô, 31-years-old from Hokkaido, 2nd class officer, censor at the Japanese embassy in Paris, France, photographed by Jacques-Philippe Potteau in 1864. The Second Japanese Embassy to Europe, also called the Ikeda Mission, was sent on 6 February 1864 by the Tokugawa shogunate. The objective of the mission was to obtain French agreement to the closure of the harbor of Yokohama to foreign trade. The task proved impossible, as Yokohama was the center of foreign presence in Japan since the opening of the country by Commodore Matthew Perry in 1854. Credit: @julius.backman⁠ #history #japan #paris

A baby in a baby cage photographed in London, England in 1934. A baby cage was a bed in a wire cage suspended from city apartment windows. They were invented to provide babies with fresh air and sunshine while living in crowded cities with a lack of homes with outdoor space. They were very popular in London in the 1930s but popularity declined through the mid-1900s, possibly due to safety concerns and the rise of urban automobile traffic. Credit: @color_byangelina⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #london #historycolored

A street in New York City photographed during the Great Blizzard of 1888. The blizzard was one of the most severe recorded blizzards in American history, with up to 58 inches (147cm) of snow falling in parts of the Eastern United States and Eastern Canada. Sustained winds of 45mph (72 km/h) caused snowdrifts over 50 feet (15m) 400 people died and $25 million (equivalent to $840 million in 2025) of property damage occurred during the blizzard. Restored footage from 1917 of 26th President of the United States Theodore Roosevelt talking to suffragist Vira Boarman Whitehouse at his home Sagamore Hill in Cove Neck, New York, United States during the opening of the second New York State suffrage campaign. Theodore Roosevelt supported women’s suffrage and in this footage is shown supporting and assisting in the campaigning for an amendment to the New York State Constitution to give women the right to vote. This amendment was successfully approved on the 6th November 1917, just under 3 years before the 19th Amendment was ratified, giving women in all of the United States the right to vote. Two Royal Navy sailors of the HMS Hood posing for a photograph with the ship's mascot Bill, a white Bull Terrier dog. Photograph taken in 1940. The HMS Hood sank on the 24 May 1941 during the Battle of Denmark Strait when it was hit by multiple German shells. The ship sank within three minutes and all but 3 of the 1,418 crew on board died. The mascot Bill had left the ship in early 1941 prior to the battle. Albert McDowell, the sailor on the left, died during the Battle. The identity and fate of the sailor on the right is unknown. Credit: @colourisedpieceofjake⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #ww2 #navy

Hattie McDaniel photographed with her Academy Award for Best Actress in a Supporting Role awarded for her performance in Gone with the Wind (1939). McDaniel was the first African-American to win an Oscar, doing so at the 12th Academy Awards on the 29 February 1940. From the 9th Academy Awards until the 16th Academy Awards, winners of the 'Best Supporting' awards were given plaques instead of statuettes. McDaniel's attendance at the event was initially in doubt as the Cocoanut Grove nightclub, which was hosting the Oscars, was racially segregated and would have typically stopped her from entering the venue. Gone with the Wind film producer David O. Selznick made arrangements to allow McDaniel to attend but she was still required to sit on a segregated table at the back of the room away from her Gone with the Wind co-stars and other attendees. Credit: @marinaarts⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #oscars #hattiemcdaniel

A still from the Charlie Chaplin silent film "A Dog's Life" which shows Charlie Chaplin as his famous character "The Tramp" sitting with Scraps the dog. The film was released in April 1918. Credit: @sebcolorisation⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #chaplin #adogslife
An American soldier resting on the street of the town square in Marigny, Normandy, France. Photograph taken on the 28 July 1944. Credit: @sebcolorisation⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #ww2 #soldier

Portrait of the Duchess of Santoña, Eugenia María Fitz-James Stuart y Falcó, and her two sons Carlos Alfonso (right) and Jaime (left), wearing reproductions of British military uniforms. Photograph taken in Madrid in 1915. ⁠ ⁠ Eugenia was a Spanish noblewoman who belonged to the noble house of FitzJames Stuart which had Scottish origins. It was founded by James FitzJames, 1st Duke of Berwick, who was the illegitimate child of King James VII of Scotland (James II of England). ⁠ ⁠ The family was proud of their British origins and showed support for the British and their allies during World War I. Carlos Alfonso also had a close friendship with Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip. ⁠ ⁠ Credit: @blaucolorizations⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #ww1 #spain

An IWW volunteer of the “Second Division” photographed on a horse in front of the Cantina Tijuana Saloon in Tijuana, Mexico during the Magonista rebellion of 1911. The Magonistas controlled Tijuana and Mexicali from January 1911 until June 1911 when the rebellion was suppressed by forces loyal to Francisco I. Madero. Restored footage from 1913 of people working on the excavations at the Jebel Moya archaeological site in the southern Gezira Plain, Sudan. The excavation was led by Sir Henry Wellcome from 1911 to 1914 and in that time a fifth of the 104,000m2 (25 acre) site was excavated. Almost 2,800 burials were excavated, finding evidence that dates use of the site to between 5000 BCE-500 CE. During the 35 years between the excavation and the first official report published in 1949, many of the skeletons and artifcats excavated were lost due to poor storage conditions. For example, the warehouse that housed some of the items flooded in 1928.   Footage frame rate increased, upscaled and “colorized” by HistoryColored using AI technology.  Footage originally from: A day at Gebel Moya, season 1912-13. Item 3., Wellcome Collection  #history #jebelmoya #sudan #archaeology #restored #historicalfootage

The iconic London Milkman photograph taken by Fred Morley on the 9 October 1940 following a a German bombing raid in London, United Kingdom. While the photograph was taken on a destroyed street following a German bombing raid, the "milkman" was actually the photographer's assistant. Fred Morley explained that he did this because he wanted to photograph the desolation that took place during the Blitz but to get around the government's censorship of demoralizing images, he added an element of normalcy to the photo e.g. a milkman continuing his duties. Credit: @color_byangelina⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #ww2 #london

A platform of the Marble Arch London tube station photographed in c. 1900. Marble Arch station was opened on 30 July 1900 by the Central London Railway (CLR). The CLR served 13 stations and ran underground for 9.14 km (5.68 mi) between its western terminus at Shepherd's Bush and its eastern terminus at Bank. The CLR was nicknamed the 'Twopenny Tube' as it charged a flat rate of two pence for a journey between any two stations. The railway was popular, carrying almost 15 million passengers by the end of 1900. Credit: @color_byangelina⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #london #undergound

A French citizen carries leaflets with the words "L'as-tu-vue? la joconde!!" which translates to "Have you seen her? the Mona Lisa!" in 1911.⁠ ⁠ On 21 August 1911, the painting was stolen from the Louvre. French poet Guillaume Apollinaire came under suspicion and was arrested and imprisoned. Apollinaire implicated his friend Pablo Picasso, who was brought in for questioning. Both were later exonerated. The real culprit was Louvre employee Vincenzo Peruggia, who had helped construct the painting's glass case. He carried out the theft by entering the building during regular hours, hiding in a broom closet, and walking out with the painting hidden under his coat after the museum had closed. Peruggia was an Italian patriot who believed that Leonardo Da Vinci's painting should have been returned to an Italian museum. The Mona Lisa remained in his apartment for 2 years until he was caught trying to sell it. Credit: @lorenzofolli_history_in_color⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #monalisa #art

Veteran of the American Revolutionary War, Daniel Waldo, photographed at the age of 101 in 1864.⁠ ⁠ Rev. Daniel Waldo was 101 years old at the time of the photo and he died on July 30th, 1864, not long after this image was taken from injuries received falling down a flight of stairs in his home in Syracuse, New York. Waldo was originally drafted into the Continental Army in 1778 at the age of 16 for a month’s service but decided to enlist in the Army. He was eventually captured and taken prisoner in March 1779 and kept in a Sugar house prison. After his release by exchange, he went back to his hometown in Windham, Connecticut to work on a farm.⁠ ⁠ Following the war, Daniel Waldo attended Yale College and graduated in 1788. He went on to become a pastor of a church and married Mary Hanchett, having 5 children with her. At the age of 96, on the 22nd December 1856, he became the chaplain of the House of Representatives. Credit: @julius.colorization⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #revolutionarywar #ushistory #veteran #americanrevolutionarywar

The Hancocks & Co. stand at the 1873 Vienna World's Fair, showcasing their jewelry and silverware. Hancocks & Co. is a jeweler in London, England, founded in 1849 by Charles Frederick Hancock. Throughout the 19th century, Hancocks & Co. exhibited at all major World's Fairs. Brothers Orville Wright (1st photo) and Wilbur Wright (2nd photo) photographed in 1905. The Wright brothers are American aviation pioneers generally credited with inventing, building, and flying the world's first successful motor-operated airplane. They made the first controlled, sustained flight of a powered, heavier-than-air aircraft with the Wright Flyer on December 17, 1903, 4 mi (6 km) south of Kitty Hawk, North Carolina, at what is now known as Kill Devil Hills (3rd photo). Credit: @socolorization⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #wright #aviation

Two photographs of Evgeny Stepanovich Kobytev, a Soviet soldier, taken 4 years apart before and after his time as a soldier in World War II. The first image was taken the day he went to the front aged 30 in June 1941, and the second photograph was taken when he returned from the war in 1945. ⁠ ⁠ In September 1941, Kobytev was wounded and became a prisoner of war imprisoned at the Khorol concentration camp. 90,000 people died in this camp. He escaped from captivity in 1943 and rejoined the army until the war ended.  After the war, Kobytev became an art teacher and created art inspired by his experiences in the army. He died in 1973 at the age of 62⁠. historycolored.com⁠ #history #soldier #ww2

English artist George Marston photographed in Antarctica in c. 1914 during the Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition led by Sir Ernest Shackleton. He twice accompanied Sir Ernest Shackleton on expeditions to Antarctic, first from 1907 to 1909 on the Nimrod expedition and then later from 1914 to 1917 on the Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition. Marston was hired as an artist for the expedition. And while stranded on Elephant Island, gave up oil paints to be used to help caulk the James Caird boat for the successful journey to find rescue on the island of South Georgia, where the whaling station Stromness was located. Credit: @polar_history_in_colour historycolored.com #history #antarctica #georgemarston

The 9th MOST LIKED Photo of 2023: American explorer Robert Peary on the deck of the SS Roosevelt in c. 1908 before setting sail on an expedition to reach the North Pole. Peary is best known for, in April 1909, leading an expedition that claimed to be the first to have reached the geographic North Pole. However, it is speculated by polar explorers and historians that he did not actually reach the pole but came within 60 miles (97km). There is also debate among polar historians as to whether Peary actually believed he reached the North Pole or if he deliberately lied. The iconic London Milkman photograph taken by Fred Morley on the 9 October 1940 following a a German bombing raid in London, United Kingdom. While the photograph was taken on a destroyed street following a German bombing raid, the "milkman" was actually the photographer's assistant. Fred Morley explained that he did this because he wanted to photograph the desolation that took place during the Blitz but to get around the government's censorship of demoralizing images, he added an element of normalcy to the photo e.g. a milkman continuing his duties. A street in New York City photographed during the Great Blizzard of 1888. The blizzard was one of the most severe recorded blizzards in American history, with up to 58 inches (147cm) of snow falling in parts of the Eastern United States and Eastern Canada. Sustained winds of 45mph (72 km/h) caused snowdrifts over 50 feet (15m). 400 people died and $25 million (equivalent to $810 million in 2023) of property damage occurred during the blizzard. Credit: @color_byangelina⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #nyc #newyorkcity

Restored footage from 1918 of future 30th President of the United States Calvin Coolidge filmed on the porch of his home is Massachusetts, United States, during his campaign for election to become the Governor of Massachusetts. He went on to win the election, becoming the 48th Governor of Massachusetts from 1919 until 1921 when he became Vice President of the United States. He remained as Vice President until 1923 when the death of President Warren G. Harding occurred and Coolidge succeeded him as President. Coolidge successfully held the office of the Presidency at the 1924 election but decided not to seek re-election at the 1928 presidential election.  Footage frame rate increased, upscaled, and “colorized” by HistoryColored using AI technology.  Footage originally from: Library of Congress  #history #calvincoolidge #coolidge #massachusetts #president #restored

There is also debate among polar historians as to whether Peary actually believed he reached the North Pole or if he deliberately lied. The youngest US Serviceman to serve and fight during WWII, Calvin Graham, who was serving in the United States Navy at 12 years old as a gunner on the USS South Dakota. Graham lied about his age and enlisted in August 1942 and took part in the Battle of Guadalcanal, in which he was hit by shrapnel while taking a hand message to an officer. While wounded himself, Graham aided in rescue efforts, assisting in pulling the wounded aboard the ship and to safety. For his actions, he received the Bronze Star Medal and the Purple Heart, but these were revoked when it was revealed that he had lied about his age, and he was dishonorably discharged from the Navy on the 1 April 1943. All his medals were eventually re-bestowed posthumously by 1994. Credit: @colourisedpieceofjake⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #navy #usa
French watchmen in a trench during World War I (1914-1918). Credit: @history_and_colorization⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #wwi #france

Men of the Japanese Antarctic Expedition of 1910-1912 photographed in c. 1911 on the deck of their ship Kainan Maru with two sled dogs. The expedition, which was the first such expedition by a non-European nation, was led by Army reserve Lieutenant Nobu Shirase. It took place at the same time as two other major Antarctic expeditions led respectively by Roald Amundsen and Robert Falcon Scott, and has been relatively overlooked in polar history. After failing to land in its first season, the Japanese expedition's original aim of reaching the South Pole was replaced by less ambitious objectives, and after a more successful second season, it returned safely to Japan without injury or loss of life. Credit: @polar_history_in_colour⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #japan #antarctica #historycolored

A man called Ford Cornwall, who was supporting the coal miners, photographed holding a rifle in 1914 in Ludlow, Las Animas County, Colorado, during the Colorado Coalfield War. Credit: @julius.colorization⁠ ⁠ The Colorado Coalfield War was a major labor uprising in the Southern and Central Colorado Front Range between September 1913 and December 1914. Striking began in late summer 1913, organized by the United Mine Workers of America (UMWA) against the Rockefeller-owned Colorado Fuel and Iron (CF&I) after years of deadly working conditions and low pay. Tensions climaxed on the 20 April 1914 when soldiers from the Colorado National Guard and private guards employed by CF&I attacked a tent colony of 1,200 striking coal miners and their families in Ludlow, Colorado. Known as the Ludlow Massacre, approximately 21 people (including 12 children) were killed. In retaliation, armed miners attacked dozens of mines and other targets over the next ten days, killing strikebreakers, destroying property, and engaging in several skirmishes with the National Guard. Violence mostly ended with the arrival of federal troops in late April 1914, but the strike did not end until December 1914. No concessions were made to the strikers. Described as the "bloodiest labor dispute in American history," an estimated 69 to 199 people died during the strike.⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #ushistory #historycolored

Brothers Auguste (left) and Louis (right) Lumière photographed together in 1895. The Lumière Brothers are best known as pioneers in photography and cinema. The brothers created the Cinématographe Lumière, which was one of the first motion-picture cameras, produced a collection of short films, and held some of the first public screenings of motion-pictures. As a result, they are widely known as the "Fathers of Cinema." They also produced an early form of color photography called Autochrome Lumière. Credit: @lorenzofolli_history_in_color⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #lumiere #cinema

Irish seaman and Antarctic explorer Thomas Crean photographed in 1915 aboard the Endurance in Antarctica during the Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition of 1914–1917 led by Ernest Shackleton. The Endurance was trapped in ice for 492 days and sank, so the 28-man crew had to use lifeboats to reach the uninhabited Elephant Island. Crean was one of 6 members of the crew to make the 800 miles (1300 km) journey from Elephant Island to South Georgia in the small-boat James Caird to seek rescue for the rest of the crew. Once they reached South Georgia after 17 days at sea, 3 of the men, including Tom Crean, trekked across the island for 36 hours continuously to a whaling station on the north side of South Georgia. There they were able to organize rescue efforts for the 3 men left on the south of the island and the remaining crew on Elephant Island. The entire crew of the Endurance returned home without loss of life. Credit: @polar_history_in_colour⁠ ⁠ Second Photo - The launching of the James Caird from the shore of Elephant Island.⁠ ⁠ Third Photo - Some of the crew stranded on Elephant Island waving goodbye to the sailors on the James Caird as they seek rescue.⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #antarctica #endurance

Veteran of the American Revolutionary War, Daniel Waldo, photographed at the age of 101 in 1864.⁠ ⁠ Rev. Daniel Waldo was 101 years old at the time of the photo, and he died on July 30th, 1864, not long after this image was taken from injuries received falling down a flight of stairs in his home in Syracuse, New York. Waldo was originally drafted into the Continental Army in 1778 at the age of 16 for a month’s service but decided to enlist in the Army. He was eventually captured and taken prisoner in March 1779 and kept in a Sugar house prison. After his release by exchange, he returned to his hometown in Windham, Connecticut to work on a farm.⁠ ⁠ Following the war, Daniel Waldo attended Yale College and graduated in 1788. He became a church pastor and married Mary Hanchett, having 5 children with her. Credit: @julius.colorization⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #americanrevolutionarywar #veteran

American soldier Jack H. Pulliam photographed shortly after being rescued by the men of the 4th Infantry Divison of the US Army in Prüm, Germany on the 13 February 1945. The earliest photograph of the White House in Washington, D.C. that is known to exist. It was taken in 1846 during the 11th President of the United States, James K. Polk's time in office. A Fijian man photographed in 1880. He is wearing a "Wasekaseka" which is a sperm whale’s tooth necklace from Fiji which was typical neck-dress of a high-ranking tribesman. The man is also carrying a Fijian War Club. These clubs come in many different types with different shapes and decorations. Clubs were very important objects in the lives of Fijian men - War Clubs were often family heirlooms passed through generations and were imbued with great Mana or spiritual power. The type of tree and wood used was very specialized, and the club was also made to size for the person who was to use it. Credit: @colourisedpieceofjake⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #fiji #historycolored

Two soldiers pay their respects at a British First World War cemetery in France a few days before the 21st anniversary of the Armistice in November 1939. Credit: @dansteelecolour⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #soldiers #historycolored

Restored footage from c. 1926 of members of the Tulsa Business League leaving to attend lunch with Solomon Sir Jones, the person that recorded this footage.  Tulsa was home to the Greenwood district, also known as “Black Wall Street”, which was one of the most affluent majority black communities in the United States. In 1921, the Tulsa race massacre occurred in which the homes, businesses and lives of black residents of Tulsa were attacked, leaving between 100-300 people killed, and over 8,000 residents left homeless. Many black residents were denied insurance claims on the damaged property so either left the city or had to rebuild their homes and businesses in the following years without insurance money.  Footage originally from: Solomon Sir Jones, Yale Collection  Footage frame rate increased, upscaled, and “colorized” using AI technology.  #history #tulsa #oklahoma #usa #unitedstates #restored

Otto Reeves (left) and Frank Alexander (right) of the Mackenzie-Papineau Battalion photographed in Spain in December 1937. Reeves and Alexander were Americans who volunteered to travel to Spain to fight on the Republican side in the Spanish Civil War. Otto Reeves would be killed in action on the 17 April 1938, and Frank Alexander would be wounded in July 1938 but would survive the conflict. He served in World War II with the all-Black 93rd Division. He was a First Sergeant and served in the Pacific during the Guadalcanal campaign. Following the war, he built a successful business as a contractor and hardware store owner in Seattle, and passed away in April 1996. Credit: @julius.colorization⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #spain #usa

English artist George Marston photographed in Antarctica in c. 1914 during the Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition led by Sir Ernest Shackleton. He twice accompanied Sir Ernest Shackleton on expeditions to Antarctic, first from 1907 to 1909 on the Nimrod expedition and then later from 1914 to 1917 on the Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition. Marston was hired as an artist for the expedition. And while stranded on Elephant Island, gave up oil paints to be used to help caulk the James Caird boat for the successful journey to find rescue on the island of South Georgia, where the whaling station Stromness was located. Credit: @polar_history_in_colour⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #antarctica #georgemarston

A group of convicts including blues musician Eugene "Buddy" Moss (holding the guitar) playing and dancing to music at the Greene County prison camp in Georgia, United States, in May 1941. In 1936, Moss was arrested and tried for the shooting murder of his wife and was convicted and sentenced to prison. By the combination of Moss' own good behavior as a prisoner and the entreaties of two outside sponsors (Long and Columbia Records) willing to ensure his compliance with parole, Moss was released from prison in 1941. Moss continued performing in the area around Richmond, Virginia, and Durham, North Carolina, during the mid-1940s. He performed again with Weaver in Atlanta during the early 1950s, but music was no longer able to maintain a living. He went to work on a tobacco farm, drove trucks, and worked as an elevator operator, among other jobs, over the next 20-odd years. Credit: @rishicolors⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #unitedstates #greenecounty

The "Flag War" of Flensburg photographed in 1920. After the First World War, due to the Treaty of Versailles, two referendums were held to decide whether the former Duchy of Schleswig would remain as part of Germany or join Denmark. In Northern Schleswig, they voted to join Denmark. In the days leading up to the Central Schleswig referendum, the buildings in the town of Flensburg were covered in flags from Germany and Denmark to show the people's allegiances. Those loyal to Denmark would fly the Dannebrog, red with a white Nordic cross, and the supporters of Germany would fly either the black-white-red tricolor flag that was previously the national flag of Germany (but had been changed after the First World War) or the blue-white-red tricolor flag of Schleswig-Holstein. Central Schleswig voted to remain a part of Germany in the referendum. Credit: @julius.colorization⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #germany #flensburg

A French citizen carries leaflets with the words "L'as-tu-vue? the joconde!!" which translates to "Have you seen her? the Mona Lisa!" in 1911.⁠ ⁠ On 21 August 1911, the painting was stolen from the Louvre. French poet Guillaume Apollinaire came under suspicion and was arrested and imprisoned. Apollinaire implicated his friend Pablo Picasso, who was brought in for questioning. Both were later exonerated. The real culprit was Louvre employee Vincenzo Peruggia, who had helped construct the painting's glass case. He carried out the theft by entering the building during regular hours, hiding in a broom closet, and walking out with the painting hidden under his coat after the museum had closed. Peruggia was an Italian patriot who believed that Leonardo Da Vinci's painting should have been returned to an Italian museum. The Mona Lisa remained in his apartment for 2 years until he was caught trying to sell it. Credit: @lorenzofolli_history_in_color⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #monalisa #art

Charging the battery of a Detroit Electric automobile in 1919. The Detroit Electric was produced by the Anderson Electric Car Company, starting in 1907, and was powered by a rechargeable lead acid battery. For an additional US$600, an Edison nickel-iron battery was available from 1911 to 1916. The cars were advertised as reliably getting 80 miles (130 km) between battery recharging, although in one test, a Detroit Electric ran 211.3 miles (340.1 km) on a single charge. Credit: @color_byangelina⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #electriccar #historycolored

A Parisian man after trying Coca-Cola for the first time photographed in the 1950s. In 1950, Coca-Cola started a marketing campaign targeting the drink to the people of France. Under the slogan “Drink Fresh,” vans toured the streets, and salesmen distributed samples to adults and children in what Coke now calls “La révolution du froid” (The cold revolution). Coca-Cola had been available in France since 1919, but after World War 2 ended, Coke decided to raise its profile and capitalize on the proliferation of refrigerators in French homes. Credit: @jsk.colorization⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #coke #cocacola

American pilot and commander during World War II, Nancy Harkness Love, photographed with a Fairchild PT-19a aircraft. Working as a test pilot and air racer in the 1930s, during World War II, she convinced Officer of the United States Army Air Forces William H. Tunner to set up a group of female pilots to ferry aircraft from factories to air bases. This proposal was eventually approved as the Women's Auxiliary Ferrying Squadron. Love commanded this unit and later all ferrying operations in the newly formed Women Airforce Service Pilots. She was awarded the Air Medal for her work during the war and was appointed lieutenant colonel in the US Air Force Reserve in 1948. Credit: @hpr_color⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #nancyharknesslove #pilot #aircraft
Portrait of two American soldiers photographed by Catherine Anne during World War I. Credit: @melodie_colors_the_past⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #ww1 #soldiers

Tsar Nicholas II of Russia (furthest away from the camera) swimming in the Black Sea in c. 1913 with his youngest sister Grand Duchess Olga Alexandrovna of Russia, and his two eldest daughters Grand Duchess Olga Nikolaevna of Russia and Grand Duchess Tatiana Nikolaevna of Russia. Co-founders of the fast-food chain McDonald's, brothers Richard and Maurice McDonald, standing by a sign outside their restaurant in San Bernardino, California in November 1948 while it was closed for three months for alterations. In December 1948 it reopened as a self-service drive-in restaurant. At the time, their menu was 9 items: hamburger, cheeseburger, soft drinks, milk, coffee, potato chips, and a slice of pie. The staple of the menu was the 15 cent hamburger. Credit: @color_byangelina⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #mcdonalds #food

A 24-year-old Joseph Vissarionovich Dzhugashvili (Joseph Stalin) photographed by the Batumi Regional Gendarmerie Department in 1902. Joseph Stalin became leader of the Soviet Union in the 1920s and remained in power until his death in March 1953. Restored footage from 1894 of legendary bodybuilder and strongman Eugen Sandow striking a variety of poses to demonstrate his muscular physique.  Sandow toured the world in the late 1800s and early 1900s partaking in various bodybuilding and strongman competitions. In 1901, he organized the world’s first major bodybuilding competition, judging the competition alongside sculptor Charles Lawes-Wittewronge and author of the iconic Sherlock Holmes novels, Arthur Conan Doyle. Sandow is seen as the father of modern bodybuilding, being one of the pioneers in intentionally developing his musculature to predetermined dimensions. He authored several books on the strategies to develop the muscles, worked on improving exercise equipment, and opened gymnasiums that were open to the public for exercise.  Footage originally from: Library of Congress Footage set to 60fps, upscaled, and “colorized” using AI technology. #history #bodybuilding #strongman #sandow #eugensandow

Men of the Japanese Antarctic Expedition of 1910-1912 photographed in c. 1911 on the deck of their ship Kainan Maru with two sled dogs. The expedition, which was the first such expedition by a non-European nation, was led by Army reserve Lieutenant Nobu Shirase. It took place at the same time as two other major Antarctic expeditions led respectively by Roald Amundsen and Robert Falcon Scott, and has been relatively overlooked in polar history. After failing to land in its first season, the Japanese expedition's original aim of reaching the South Pole was replaced by less ambitious objectives, and after a more successful second season, it returned safely to Japan without injury or loss of life. Credit: @polar_history_in_colour⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #japan #antarctica #historycolored

Maharaja Sir Bhupinder Singh of Patiala photographed in 1911. Maharaja Sir Bhupinder Singh was an Indian royal and cricket player. Edman Spangler, an American carpenter, and stagehand who was employed at Ford's Theatre at the time of President Abraham Lincoln's assassination on 14 April 1865. He and seven others were charged in conspiring to assassinate Lincoln and three other high-level government officials but was the only one found not guilty of the conspiracy charge. However, he was found guilty of helping Lincoln's assassin, John Wilkes Booth, escape and sentenced to six years of hard labor. Photograph taken on the 17 April 1865 in Washington Navy Yard, D.C. Veteran of the American Revolutionary War, Daniel Waldo, photographed at the age of 101 in 1864.⁠ ⁠ Rev. Daniel Waldo was 101 years old at the time of the photo and he died on July 30th, 1864, not long after this image was taken from injuries received falling down a flight of stairs in his home in Syracuse, New York. Waldo was originally drafted into the Continental Army in 1778 at the age of 16 for a month’s service but decided to enlist in the Army. He was eventually captured and taken prisoner in March 1779 and kept in a Sugar house prison. After his release by exchange, he went back to his hometown in Windham, Connecticut to work on a farm.⁠ ⁠ Following the war, Daniel Waldo attended Yale College and graduated in 1788. He went on to become a pastor of a church and married Mary Hanchett, having 5 children with her. At the age of 96, on the 22nd December 1856, he became the chaplain of the House of Representatives. Credit: @julius.colorization⁠ historycolored.com⁠ #history #revolutionarywar #ushistory #veteran #americanrevolutionarywar

An African-American veteran of World War I faces off against a member of the Illinois state militia during the Chicago Race Riot of 1919. The Chicago race riot of 1919 was a violent racial conflict started by white Americans against black Americans that began on the South Side of Chicago, Illinois, on July 27 and ended on August 3, 1919. During the riot, 38 people died (23 black and 15 white). Over the week, injuries attributed to the episodic confrontations stood at 537, with two-thirds of the injured being black and one-third white, and approximately 1,000 to 2,000 lost their homes. Due to its sustained violence and widespread economic impact, it is considered the worst of the scores of riots and civil disturbances across the United States during the "Red Summer" of 1919. The state militia was brought in to police the riot and restore order. Credit: @john_colour⁠ historycolored.com⁠ @historyblackandwhite to see the original black and white version.⁠ #history #chicago #usa

The 92nd Infantry Division was a segregated infantry division of the US Army and the only African American infantry division to see combat in Europe during World War II, as part of the US Fifth Army, fighting in the Italian Campaign. Carl Emil Pettersson photographed in c. 1890 who was a Swedish sailor who became king of Tabar Island in Papua New Guinea after he was shipwrecked in 1904. On a recruiting trip in the Pacific, Pettersson's vessel sank on Christmas Day 1904, off Tabar Island in New Ireland Province. He was washed ashore near a village where he was immediately surrounded by islanders. The islanders carried him to their king, and the king's daughter fell in love with him. In 1907 he married Princess Singdo, the daughter of the local king, Lamy. He got a start in the copra trade and managed to create his own coconut plantation that he called Teripax. He became king after the death of his father-in-law. His nickname among the locals was "Strong Charley", and he was famed for his physical strength. Swedish newspapers printed a series of stories about Pettersson and his adventures. Credit: @julius.colorization⁠ historycolored.com⁠ @historyblackandwhite to see the original black and white version.⁠ #history #papuanewguinea #sailor

Gogea Mitu fought twice in 1935, winning both by knockout, and then never fought again. The coronation of Queen Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom photographed in Westminster Abbey, London, United Kingdom on the 2 June 1953. Elizabeth II acceded to the throne at the age of 25 upon the death of her father, George VI, on 6 February 1952, being proclaimed queen by her privy and executive councils shortly afterwards. The coronation was held more than one year later because of the tradition of allowing an appropriate length of time to pass after a monarch dies before holding such festivals. Today, Elizabeth celebrates her Platinum Jubilee, commemorating her 70th anniversary on the throne. Mugshot of Solomon Sivils who was sentenced to 18 months and fined $10 for introducing liquor into Indian Territory in 1904. The reservation ban on alcohol, coupled with a prohibition of Native Americans being sold or consuming alcohol even off reservations, would continue for over a century, even after the 21st Amendment ended national prohibition. Famous photograph of Nikola Tesla sat with his equipment in his laboratory in Colorado Springs, Colorado, USA in c. 1899. The truth of the photo is that it was actually a double exposure shot and Tesla was not actually sitting with the equipment while it was on. Photographer Dickenson V. Alley first photographed the room while the machines were on and sparking. Then the photographic plate was exposed again with the machine off and Nikola Tesla sitting in the chair.
